properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued July 1 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
properties.description:
At 1259 AM CDT, radar indicated strong thunderstorms were located
along a line extending from Wanamingo to near Freeborn. Movement was
east at 45 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph and heavy rainfall are possible with these
storms.

These storms will be near...
Mazeppa around 120 AM CDT.
Plainview, Hayfield and Brownsdale around 145 AM CDT.
Grand Meadow around 200 AM CDT.

Other locations impacted by these storms include South Troy, I 90
Exit 218, Potsdam, Eden, Highway 57 And 570th Street, County Roads 6
And 15, Hidden Meadows R V Park, Rock Dell, Brookside Campground and
County Roads 5 And 6.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with these storms, and may cause
localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

NWSheadline: A LINE OF STRONG THUNDERSTORMS WILL AFFECT OLMSTED...NORTHERN MOWER...SOUTHERN WABASHA AND DODGE COUNTIES

properties.areaDesc: La Crosse; Clayton; Chickasaw; Houston; Dodge; Howard; Fillmore; Mitchell; Fayette; Winona; Richland; Trempealeau; Olmsted; Winneshiek; Floyd; Mower; Buffalo; Vernon; Crawford; Grant; Allamakee; Wabasha
properties.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued July 1 at 12:59AM CDT until July 1 at 12:00PM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
properties.description:
The risk for flash flooding has increased over the past hours. A
period of thunderstorms is expected through the early morning
hours. These thunderstorms will be capable of producing heavy
rainfall rates. Wet soils from the rainy pattern, and previous
flooding over the past week, will lead to a higher threat of
rapid onset flooding should storms repeat over certain areas.
The National Weather Service in La Crosse has issued a

* Flash Flood Watch for portions of Iowa, southeast Minnesota,
and Wisconsin, including the following areas, in Iowa,
Allamakee, Chickasaw, Clayton, Fayette, Floyd, Howard,
Mitchell, and Winneshiek. In southeast Minnesota, Dodge,
Fillmore, Houston, Mower, Olmsted, Wabasha, and Winona. In
Wisconsin, Buffalo, Crawford, Grant, La Crosse, Richland,
Trempealeau, and Vernon.

* Until noon CDT today

* Thunderstorms with heavy rain are expected in the watch area
through the morning. Local areas that see repeat thunderstorms
will be prone to flooding.

* Urban flooding and rapid rises on creeks, streams, and rivers
are all possible.

* Those camping near any creeks or streams, especially in steep
terrain, should seek higher ground away from water if
thunderstorms persist.
properties.instruction:
A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions may develop that lead
to flash flooding. Flash flooding is a very dangerous situation.

You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

NWSheadline: FLASH FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON CDT TODAY

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 30 at 11:58PM MDT until July 2 at 11:52AM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
properties.description:
Eagle River AT Red Cliff affecting Eagle County


.The Eagle River is expected to increase a few more inches overnight
due to snowmelt and rainfall from earlier showers and thunderstorms.
One of the bridges over Turkey Creek has been inundated with water.
A few homes have also experienced some minor flooding. Caution
should be taken along the Eagle River and Turkey Creek due to this
minor flooding.
The National Weather Service in Grand Junction CO has issued a
* Flood Advisory for
The Eagle River AT Red Cliff.
* until Tuesday morning.
* At 10 PM Sunday the stage was 5.2 feet.
* Bankfull stage is 5.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Caution is urged when walking near waterways. Avoid
flooded areas and unstable riverbanks. Stay tuned to developments by
listening to NOAA Weather Radio or your local TV or radio stations.

Additional information can also be found on the NWS Grand Junction
homepage at weather.gov/gjt

properties.areaDesc: Central U.S. Waters Strait Of Juan De Fuca; East Entrance U.S. Waters Strait Of Juan De Fuca
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued June 30 at 10:45PM PDT until July 1 at 2:00AM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
properties.description:
* WIND AND WAVES...West winds 15 to 25 knots tonight and 25 to 35
knots Monday night. Wind waves 2 to 4 feet tonight and 4 to 7
feet Monday night.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

A Gale Watch is issued when the risk of gale force winds of 34 to
47 knots has significantly increased, but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.

properties.areaDesc: Western Prince William Sound; Anchorage; Copper River Basin; Susitna Valley; Matanuska Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 30 at 8:49PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage, AK
properties.description:
High river conditions are expected along the Matanuska, Skwentna,
Klutina, Eagle River, Sixmile, Talkeetna, Kenai at Cooper
Landing, Kenai Keys, and Kenai below Skilak Lake. Water levels are
expected to continue and/or rise into Action Stage and Bankfull
conditions until Friday Jul 5. No significant impacts are
expected along these rivers.

A Flood Warning has been issued for the Yentna River at Fish
Creek.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 30 at 11:32PM CDT until July 1 at 11:45AM CDT by NWS Topeka KS
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Topeka has extended the

* Flood Warning for...
Northwestern Jefferson County in northeastern Kansas...

* Until 1145 AM CDT Monday.

* Emergency Management indicates flooding along the Delaware river
due to backwater from Lake Perry continues to inundate parts of
the city of Valley Falls. Specifically, areas around Sycamore and
Maple Road including the park and ball fields are inundated.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Valley Falls.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Keep children away from storm drains, culverts, creeks and streams.
Water levels can rise rapidly and sweep children away.

properties.areaDesc: Stanley, SD; Hughes, SD; Sully, SD
properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 30 at 11:31PM CDT until July 1 at 5:30AM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Aberdeen has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
South central Sully County in central South Dakota...
Central Stanley County in central South Dakota...
Northwestern Hughes County in central South Dakota...

* Until 530 AM CDT/430 AM MDT/.

* At 1131 PM CDT/1031 PM MDT/, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms
producing heavy rain across the warned area. Flash flooding is
expected to begin shortly.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Pierre, Fort Pierre, Grey Goose, Overlook Rec Area, West Shore Rec
Area and Oahe Mission Rec Area.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

Please report flooding to your local law enforcement agency when you
can do so safely.

CMAMtext: Flash Flood Warning this area til 5:30 AM CDT. Avoid flood areas. -NWS

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 30 at 10:31PM CDT by NWS Springfield MO
properties.description:
Osage River near Schell City affecting Bates and Vernon Counties
Osage River AT Taberville affecting St. Clair County
Sac River near Caplinger Mills affecting Cedar County
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio for updates or local media for
updates.

Additional river information can be found on our Advanced Hydrologic
Prediction Service page at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/
index.php?wfo=sgf

properties.description: SEE THE COASTAL WATERS FORECAST (CWFLOX) FOR MORE DETAILS.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous wind and sea
conditions will exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels, should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

NWSheadline: SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 AM PDT TUESDAY

properties.headline: Wind Advisory issued June 30 at 8:15PM PDT until July 1 at 4:00AM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Los Angeles/Oxnard has issued a
Wind Advisory, which is in effect until 4 AM PDT Monday.

* WINDS...North winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 40 mph tonight
through early Monday morning, strongest through passes and
canyons west of Goleta.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will make driving difficult, especially
for high profile vehicles. This includes Highways 101 and 154.
properties.instruction:
When driving, use extra caution. Be prepared for sudden gusty
cross winds.

NWSheadline: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM PDT MONDAY

properties.description:
Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau...Thebes and New Madrid

.Along the Mississippi River, major flooding continues at Cape
Girardeau, moderate flooding continues at Thebes, and minor flooding
continues at New Madrid. Water levels are slowly falling at all three
locations, with Cape Girardeau forecast to fall to moderate flooding
Tuesday evening. Flooding will continue at all three locations until
further notice.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 PM Sunday the stage was 42.4 feet.
* Flood Stage is 32.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The River will continue to fall to a stage of 42.0 feet
by Tuesday morning.
* Impact...At 42.0 Feet...Several homes and structures in southern
Cape Girardeau County may be inundated or cut off due to backwater
flooding from the Diversion Channel. Evacuations may be required.
Thousands of acres are flooded. Numerous roads are closed both
along the Mississippi River and due to backwater flooding.

properties.areaDesc: Wabash, IL; Knox, IN; Gibson, IN
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 30 at 10:48PM EDT until July 1 at 11:00PM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
properties.description:
Wabash River...White River...


.Flooding continues in far southwestern Indiana from the rainy
weather during a large portion of June.

Minor flooding continues on the White River at Hazleton and on the
Wabash at Mount Carmel. Flooding is expected to conclude by late July
1.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Hazleton.
* until Monday evening.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to crest at 17.7 feet late tonight and
will fall below flood stage by Monday morning.
* At 17.5 feet...Flood water is near or starting on Pottsville Road.
Low bottomlands are increasingly affected by flood waters.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

properties.areaDesc: Hidalgo, TX; Cameron, TX; Willacy, TX
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 30 at 9:27PM CDT until July 1 at 9:30AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
East central Hidalgo County in Deep South Texas...
Northwestern Cameron County in Deep South Texas...
Southwestern Willacy County in Deep South Texas...

* Until 930 AM CDT Monday.

* At 924 PM CDT, Emergency management has reported high water near
Santa Rosa, with locations along FM 5O6 still inundated with 3 to
4 feet of water. Near Sebastian, inundation of 1 to 2 feet is
still occurring. Other locations, especially near the northern
floodway are slowly improving, with inundation of around 1 foot of
water or less. Texas Department of Transportation continues to
report multiple closed roadways within the warned area.

* Some locations that are still experiencing flooding include...
Santa Rosa, Sebastian, La Villa, Combes, and Santa Monica.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

properties.headline: High Surf Advisory issued June 30 at 3:50PM HST until July 1 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
properties.description:
An energetic south-southwest swell will bring advisory level
surf to south facing shores of all islands through Monday. The
surf will peak into tonight, then gradually lower through Monday.
* SURF...8 to 12 feet with occasionally higher sets tonight,
lowering to 6 to 9 feet Monday, along south facing shores of
all islands.

* TIMING...Through 6 PM HST Monday.

* IMPACTS...Moderate...Expect strong breaking waves, shore
break, and strong longshore and rip currents making swimming
difficult and dangerous.
properties.instruction:
Beachgoers, swimmers, and surfers should heed all advice given by
ocean safety officials and exercise caution. Boaters should
expect recreational surfers and body boarders utilizing harbor
channels to access surfing areas.

NWSheadline: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM HST MONDAY

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued June 30 at 6:40PM PDT until July 5 at 3:00AM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
properties.description:
* HAZARDS...Dangerous rip currents and breaking waves are expected
due to elevated surf building to 3 to 6 feet. The surf will be
highest Wednesday into Thursday.

* TIDES...High tides near 7 feet will occur each evening between
8 PM and 10 PM Tuesday through Thursday.

* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning due to
strong currents. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out
to sea. Minor tidal overflow is expected around the time of
evening high tide due to the unusually high tides combined with
a building south swell.
properties.instruction:
A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when threats such as rip
currents...longshore currents...sneaker waves and other hazards
create life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Swim near a
lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and float. Don't
swim against the current. If able, swim in a direction following
the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or
wave for help.

NWSheadline: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH LATE THURSDAY NIGHT

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 30 at 8:27PM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
properties.description:
Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes

Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Sunday the stage was 59.3 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 59.4 feet by
Monday July 1st and then hold nearly steady for several days.
* Impact...At 59.0 feet...The east bank levee will be topped and the
prison farm land between the two levees will be inundated. Angola
Landing will be under water closing the ferry there. All river
islands along the reach from Red River Landing to Baton Rouge will
remain inundated with recreational camps and river bottom farm land
under water.
* Impact...At 58.0 feet...Angola farmland on the left bank becomes
inundated.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
* Impact...At 46.0 feet...River traffic will become dangerous. A levee
crevasse would flood adjacent farm land. Significant flooding of
Raccourci Island will continue and evacuation of the island is
recommended.
* Impact...At 45.0 feet...Between the 40 and 45 foot stage flooding of
Raccourci Island becomes significant. At the 45 foot stage
evacuation of the island is recommended.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

properties.areaDesc: San Diego County Coastal Areas; Orange County Coastal
properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued June 30 at 6:06PM PDT until July 5 at 3:00AM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in San Diego has issued a Beach
Hazards Statement, which is in effect from Tuesday morning
through late Thursday night.

* Waves and Surf...A long period southwest swell will generate
above average surf of 3 to 6 feet on Orange and San Diego County
beaches.

* Impacts...Minor tidal overflow at the beaches and harbors most
susceptible to tidal runup. This includes Seal Beach and Sunset
Beach in Orange County, and Cardiff Beach and Imperial Beach in
San Diego County. High tides near 6.7 feet will occur each
evening between 9 PM and Midnight.

* Rip Currents...Increased risk of strong rip currents that can
pull swimmers out to sea.
properties.instruction:
A beach hazards statement is issued when threats such as strong
rip currents...elevated surf heights...minor tidal overflow...or
lightning are possible at local beaches.  Obey posted warning
signs and flags and talk to a lifeguard before swimming.  Use
caution when in or near the water and always swim near a
lifeguard.

NWSheadline: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH LATE THURSDAY NIGHT

properties.description: * WINDS...18 to 33 knots within the Small Craft Advisory.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means winds of 18 to 33 knots are imminent
or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

NWSheadline: SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 AM EDT MONDAY

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 30 at 7:05PM CDT until July 2 at 10:30AM CDT by NWS Memphis TN
properties.description:
At 700 PM CDT, minor flooding continued to affect low-lying areas
adjacent to the Tennessee River in portions of Benton and extreme
eastern Henry Counties. The river is currently cresting near 362.4
feet and is expected to begin a gradual fall on Monday. Several
roads are closed in Benton County, including Harmon's Dock Road,
Bivins Cypress Creek Road, and Granny's Branch Road.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Camden, New Johnsonville, Big Sandy Unit Tennessee National Wildlife
Refuge, and Nathan Bedford Forrest State Park.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

NWSheadline: THE FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1030 AM CDT TUESDAY FOR EASTERN BENTON AND EAST CENTRAL HENRY COUNTIES

properties.areaDesc: Taiya Inlet and Klondike Highway; Haines Borough and Lynn Canal
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 30 at 11:40AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
properties.description:
Due to the recent warm weather, water levels on the Taiya and
Chilkat rivers have risen somewhat. Both rivers will likely reach
bankfull levels tonight before lowering some Monday, then rise
back to bankfull levels Monday night. Flooding is not expected at
this time. Anyone on or along these rivers should monitor water
levels closely.

NWSheadline: BANKFULL CONDITIONS LIKELY ON SOME AREA RIVERS

properties.areaDesc: Central Beaufort Sea Coast; Northeastern Brooks Range
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 30 at 11:30AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks, AK
properties.description:
Heavy rain is expected through Monday with a front pushing over
the Eastern Brooks Range. Up to one inch of rain is expected to
fall through Monday. The rainfall is expected to produce
additional rises on rivers draining the Eastern Brooks Range
through the middle of next week. Water levels are expected to
remain within banks, however those with interests along or near
rivers draining the Brooks Range should exercise caution.

NWSheadline: High Water Levels on the Sag River

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 30 at 11:08AM MDT until July 4 at 1:15PM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
properties.description:
Elevated flows along the Los Pinos River in eastern La Plata County
can be expected until further notice. Runoff above the dam is
occurring as warm temperatures have accelerated the melting of the
high elevation snowpack. Elevated releases below Vallecito Dam are
necessary to mitigate this incoming water. These warm temperatures
and possible rainfall will keep runoff high into next week.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from snow melt will cause creeks, streams and rivers
to rise. Minor flooding along the banks and in low lying areas will
be possible.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 30 at 11:00AM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
properties.description:
Gore Creek at Vail affecting Eagle County

.Warm temperatures continue to accelerate high elevation runoff from
the snowpack. This runoff will cause Gore Creek to run at bankfull
into early next week. Minor lowland flooding is possible along Gore
Creek. A slow decrease in the river level is anticipated by the mid
week period.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Gore Creek at Vail
* until further notice.
* At 10 AM Sunday the stage was 9.1 feet.
* Bankfull stage is 9.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.2 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 9.8 feet by this
evening.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Caution is urged when walking near waterways. Avoid
flooded areas and unstable riverbanks. Stay tuned to developments by
listening to NOAA Weather Radio or your local TV or radio stations.

Additional information can also be found on the NWS Grand Junction
homepage at weather.gov/gjt

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 30 at 9:53AM PDT until July 6 at 11:30AM PDT by NWS Reno NV
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Reno has extended the

* Flood Advisory for...
Snowmelt in...
North central Pershing County in west central Nevada...

* Until 1130 AM PDT Saturday.

* At 945 AM PDT Sunday, June 30, minor flooding was occurring along
the Humboldt River above Rye Patch Reservoir.

* Forecast...Minor flooding will continue through much of the
upcoming week, with the river falling very slowly. Minor flooding
may continue into the second week of July.

* Impact...Water over Tungsten Road south of the river between the
river and the Pit Taylor Canal. Some minor low land flooding near
the river from the Humboldt County line to Rye Patch Reservoir.
properties.instruction:
Runoff from snowmelt will cause minor flooding of country roads,
farmland, and other low lying spots.

properties.areaDesc: Western Prince William Sound; Anchorage; Copper River Basin; Susitna Valley; Matanuska Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 30 at 8:11AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage, AK
properties.description:
High river conditions are expected along the Matanuska, Skwentna,
Klutina, Eagle, Sixmile, Talkeetna, Kenai at Cooper Landing,
Kenai Keys, and Kenai below Skilak Lake. Water levels are
expected to continue and/or rise into Action Stage and Bankfull
conditions until Monday Jul 5. No significant impacts are expected
along these rivers.

A Flood Warning has been issued for the Yentna River at Fish
Creek.

properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

warrant.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 29 at 4:12PM AKDT until July 1 at 4:15PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Anchorage has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
Snowmelt in...YENTNA RIVER NEAR FISH CREEK

* Until 415 PM AKDT Monday.

* At 412 PM AKDT, Snow and glacial melt in the Yentna Basin have
caused river levels along the lower Yentna River below Fish Creek
to rise above Flood Stage. River levels are expected to rise
another 1 to 1.5 feet. At this time, locations adjacent to the
river at and downstream of Lake Creek are expected have water high
enough to surround some structures. Also, low lying areas adjacent
to the river are expected to be flooded. River levels are expected
to remain in Flood conditions until July 4.

Residents along this part of the river should prepare for river
levels to continue rising another one to 1.5 feet.

* Structures adjacent to the river are expected to be surrounded by
water. Low lying areas along the river will also be inundated.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 29 at 9:35AM PDT until July 3 at 4:00AM PDT by NWS Elko NV
properties.description:
THE FLOOD WARNING CONTINUES FOR
THE Humboldt River at Comus.
* Until Tuesday afternoon.
* At  8:15 AM Saturday the stage was 10.8 feet.
* FLOOD STAGE IS 9.5 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring.
* FORECAST...The river will continue to slowly fall over the weekend
into early next week and is expected to drop below minor flood stage
by Tuesday afternoon or evening.
* Impact...at 11.0 feet...Moderate to major lowland flooding
throughout the reach. Many rural roads near the river are flooded.
Minor to moderate flooding occurs in lower portions of Winnemucca.
Main area impacted is between the Union Pacific Railroad and
Golconda Street on the west and Second Street on the east, beneath
Interstate 80. This would be similar to flooding that occurred in
February 2017.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 28 at 1:20PM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
properties.description:
Missouri River near Williston affecting McKenzie and Williams
Counties
For the Missouri River Basin including Williston...Minor flooding is
occurring...With Moderate flooding forecast.

. The up and down pattern for the Missouri River near Williston will
continue into July even as the longer trend will be for lower water
levels. However, the Missouri River near Williston will remain above
flood stage until at least the middle, if not latter part of July.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River near Williston.
* until further notice.
* At 12:45 PM Friday the stage was 23.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 24.4 feet by
Tuesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Water begins to cover oil well location
south and east of Williston. Wildlife management areas are flooded.
City of Williston does not flood.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...Do not drive into areas where water tops the
roadway. Turn around...Don't drown. Avoid driving on flooded roads.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 26 at 1:58PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
properties.description:
PRZ005-006-252015-
Centro Interior-Ponce y Vecindad-
258 PM AST miercoles 26 de junio de 2019

...UNA TRONADA FUERTE AFECTARA LOS MUNICIPIOS DE VILLALBA...PONCE Y
JUANA DIAZ...

A las 255 PM AST, una tronada fuerte estaba localizada sobre
Villalba y el norte de Juan Diaz. Esta tronada esta moviendose
lentamente hacia el oeste.

Vientos en exceso de 30 mph son posibles con esta tronada. Lluvias
torrenciales tambien estan ocurriendo con esta tronada y pudieran
causar inundaciones localizadas. No maneje su vehiculo en areas
inundadas.

Rayos frecuentes de nube a suelo estan ocurriendo con esta tronada.
Los rayos pueden impactar hasta 10 millas de la tronada. Busque
refugio dentro de un edificio o vehiculo.

NWSheadline: UNA TRONADA FUERTE AFECTARA LOS MUNICIPIOS DE VILLALBA...PONCE Y JUANA DIAZ
